ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I didn't know how much variation there was in normal human functioning between industrialized and non-industrialized populations
Learned about human life history which I was unfamiliar with before the course
I learned more about human evolutionary bio and how these ideas may be applicable in our own lives.
Basics of evolutionary theory, how that applies to humans, and why that matters in current medicine and research
How human health & reproductive outcomes can be explained in relation to other animals and our inter population hormonal studies.
I learned a lot about how human's have evolved over time, especially in terms of reproduction.
I learned so much about evolution, diversity in populations of humans, and adaptation to environments!
Developed an understanding of the nuances driving human evolution and reproduction from a granular to macro level
I learned about the evolutionary advantages of certain traits of humans. The class mostly focused on reproduction
I learned a lot about the natural world in a way I had not previously: primarily through the lens of life history theory.
I gained a fairly expansive overview of evolutionary and life history perspectives on anthropology. We covered a decent range of topics and I thought the material was well-taught and interesting.

I learned a lot about trade offs in evolution- that was the theme of the course- not just in humans but how these ideas coule be applied to other species. The interaction between environment and the organism, what functions different hormones have in determining the trajectories of growth, etc.

This class is fantastic. It gives you a broad insight into the field of anthropology that is useful for science and non-science majors alike. Professor Bribiescas is engaging and highly knowledgeable about the subject material and much of our readings feature his research. Learned a lot about life history trade-offs and important aspects of human biology and life that are useful both in future classes and also in every day life.
I learned a lot of insight of content that I honestly wasn't very interested to begin with but it turned out being very fascinating material.
I learned more about anthropology and how human evolution affects our lives today.
I learned a great deal about how energy constrains human behavior, leading to trade offs that might explain differences between Western societies and non-Western ones.
Really interesting information about human reproduction, immune function, metabolism, aging, and through the lens of life history theory and human evolution.

I develop a lot better of an understanding of the human body and the evolutionary and life history forces that go into how it works. I find myself referencing what I learned in this course in casual conversation more than any other course I took this semester which is surprising because I am a social science major, not a Bio major.
Learned so much about anthro n human biology!!!
Basic information about the ways that evolution have affected our health and life histories.
I learned a great deal about evolution and the human body, and how the theory of life history explains the adaptational significance of much of how our body and lives function.
evolutionary perspectives
Gained a lot of useful knowledge about the human body and history of human evolution!
Very good survey of anthropological topics that helped me answer important questions about life that Ive always had

Learned a lot about how a variety of human biology evolved. This includes a discussion of the basics of evolution as well as the different aspects of this process which can be focused on (this class has a recurring focus on tradeoffs), and then a transition to how this has shaped a variety of different aspects of humanity, from reproductive functioning to stress.
Overall gained a better understanding of how the process and outcomes of evolution are studied in modern humans, as well as gaining a deeper knowledge of how that evolution has shaped us to this point.

The course made learning specific topics from both the readings and lectures and knowing them backwards and forwards for the midterms a requirement, and I think I improved upon this as the semester progressed .
I learned more about human anthropology and human life history, which I have never studied before

Good intro to life history and reproductive ecology. I found myself quite comfortable reading scientific papers, and learned a lot about hormones, growth and the uniqueness (and lack thereof) of humans and other great apes.
The main knowledge I gained was about life history theory. I had never heard of it before and it is a powerful and cool theory!

Interesting insight into human evolutionary biology, and great for people who don't have a huge biology background but are still somewhat interested in science. I didn't expect evolutionary processes to be so informed by energetics and energetic tradeoffs, but I guess that actually does make a lot of sense!
human evolutionary biology
General understanding of evolutionary biology and life history. The material was extremely interesting and relevant to everyday life.
I learned more about anthropology and the development of humans. I learned more about why humans and other organisms developed the way that they did.
more in depth scientific knowledge about humans and how we interact with each other and the environment. interesting material that made me think

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: readings are very approachable, even if you've never taken a science class at Yale before
Weaknesses: problem sets were usually graded very generously, but when they took points off it tended to feel arbitrary
Not that interesting of a topic

This course had some really interesting content and it was really fun to hear about prof bribiescas' experiences in the field that related to the content we were learning about. I thought that sometimes the content was organized in a way where I didn't understand how some tangents related to the main point, and some readings were extremely dense and difficult to parse through.
The p-sets were kind of BS. Would always lose a point for something silly.
This course is laid out very wellcontent progression made sense, readings closely followed the lecture material, and the midterm content was as expected. No specific weaknesses come to mind.

I liked the information that we learned, I thought it was very interesting. I think the content could be better organized. It would be nice if at the beginning of every lecture there was a slide showing the key takeaways from each day so we know where the lecture is going. I thought the exams were fair for the most part. Sometimes there were points I thought were very important because the professor harped on them a lot but then they were never tested.
Strengths are the predictable, routine syllabus and the use of technology to archive lectures and materials
The material in this course was very interests and Professor Bribiescas is a very engaging lecturer. However, my engagement in the class felt limited by the disproportionate focus on exams.

Strength: easy, psets are easy, exams were fairly easy
Weakness: tedious, lecture can be boring, readings were sometimes dense
I thought that the course was well organized, but the readings sometimes did not feel entirely relevant to the course.
I thought sections were very helpful for reviewing the psets and relevant lecture material.

strengths: I liked Dr. Bribiescas- hes a pretty good lecturer, but he is really great at explaining things one on one. The ideas from this course are broad enough to be applied to a lot of topics in evolution, not just human evolution. 
weaknesses: you have to do the readings really really well, because the exams tend to get very specific. Your TA is also going to play a big role on what you actually get out of the course, so watch out for that too.
Passionate prof. Good TAs!

Strengths: organization, like the three midterm schedule and the problem sets kept me engaged and the readings were fair and manageable
Weaknesses: Perhaps the sections could have been more organized and beneficial to understanding course material
Perhaps a few practice exams would be nice to get an idea of how the questions are

Strengths: clearly formatted, well structured
Weaknesses: I wish they had given us a clearer idea of what tests would look like/cover

The strengths: Bribiescas is a really passionate lecturer, the material really connects from different lectures

Weaknesses: there are a lot of problem sets (though not mathematical), which only sometimes help understand the material. Also, it is sometimes unclear what is a verified finding vs a hypothesis because we talk about so many explanations for human traits that defy easy evidence.

The course could be improved by summarizing the key points at the end of each unit/before each midterm. The second unit on the immune system and growth would have benefited from this because it tries to cover a lot of material on the same period of time as the others. Perhaps it would have been better to put this unit last? In general, you learn a lot about how different bodily systems work. It would have been nice to know how much we had to know about how these function vs their relevance to ev bio/life history. That would have streamlined my studying.
Lectures are enjoyable. I wouldn't necessarily say there are any weaknesses.

Strengths: manageable workload, but was still able to teach students a wide variety of information; relevant information for everyday life (especially for womens health)

Weaknesses: readings were a little long and kind of dense which was challenging without any class time spent covering the readings
It was a great course all in all

It was super interesting material but exams were super hard (felt like exams tested more of if you could memorize every word of the readings or what Professor said in class ). I came out of the class learning a lot but my exam and scores didn't reflect the amount of learning I did with the course.

As a science class for non-bio majors I think the course is well structured.  You have to do the readings/attend or watch the lectures to properly solve the problem sets and do well on midterms, but nothing is so difficult that it requires a lot of excess stress, and I enjoy what I learned. Sections exist for people who would like more assistance in understanding the material but are not optional.
variety of content but lecture is too monotonous
Strengths included the professor himself. Prof B was extremely knowledgeable and engaging. It was evident that he was very passionate about the subject, which made lecture a lot more interesting!

Strengths: Fantastic lectures, Professor Bribiescas clearly cares a lot about student engagement, sections helped make sense of readings, super manageable workload, exams are fair

Weaknesses: Lockdown browser exams were not ideal, last midterm covered a lot more content than the first two did, class took up a lot of time per week with 2x 75 min lectures and a 50 min section (section was not required but definitely beneficial)
Professor is a total gem and the pacing of the class is excellent

Strengths: You actually cover a fair bit of material, and to really feel confident going into the midterms you have to actually memorize quite a bit of it. I put this as a strength as it means you really do have to engage with the material and not just coast by, and this I consider a strength. Another strength is that the readings we do are often of actual research, which is good because it shows the actual paradigm of research in the field. The TFs/Sections I thought were a strength, as they both reviewed major themes and covered some of the harder readings in a more digestable fashion (would definitely recommend attending!). Lastly, the 3 midterm structure made it so that studying never was truly overwhelming, but the material was sufficiently cumulative that I still actually remember quite a bit of the basics from the beginning of the course.

Weaknesses: Lectures often felt like they jumped around between topics inside of each slideshow. This made it sometimes a little bit tricky to see the whole thread of the lecture and exactly how each thing related to what. This semester they recorded the lectures and made in-person attendance optional, this was a weakness as it meant relatively few people consistently came to lecture which made it less engaging and lower-energy. Lastly, some of the readings were really long and contained too high a ratio of minor-details:important-insights, which made the HW somewhat of a slog for many weeks of the course.
The course moves at an interesting pace, and is not very suitable to non-STEM majors.
Well-taught. I liked having three separate mid terms so you can really focus on the topics in between the tests.
I thought that it was an interesting class even if you are not an anthropology or science major, but it was very challenging at times.

You will read a lot of really, really dense papers. You will sit through a lot of really, really confusing lectures. The only way to do well in this course is to proactively clarify with your teaching fellow what information is and is not important. Aside from a student's own capacity to engage their teaching fellow, this course does nothing to help non-science majors digest and parse through content--pretty tough, given this is a class that a lot of folks take to fulfill their science requirement.

the midterm exams require you to study a quantity of information that began to feel overwhelming, and the format of these tests made it so that only a limited amount of what you studied would even be on the tests.

I think Professor Bribiescas lectures could be more organized. Lots of times he will have a slide at the beginning with subpoints that he will go into throughout the lecture, but then he doesn't actually go into all of them during the lecture. Or some of them are main points and some are subpoints. Taking notes in class you have to structure the info for yourself because lots of the time his internal lecture structure is confusing or unhelpful. 
Another weakness is for several concepts the level of specificity was confusing, aka how much you had to know. For some of the hormonal systems I was confused about what things meant because we didn't know basic systems that that knowledge relied on. Sometimes I felt that we knew things too superficially or too in-depth. I think a better balance could be struck.

Strengths: well organized, straightforward, interesting, engaging, and passionate prof.

Weaknesses: some parts of the course felt a bit repetitive at times but perhaps this was necessary for the course?

Weakness: very boring class; exams are all memorisation 
Strength: easy psets
Professor Bribiescas was an amazing lecturer and classes were very clear. Reading assignments were interesting as well.

Strengths: interesting content relevant to our every day lives! not a high workload -- weekly psets that were basically reading comprehension and 3 exams total. Prof. Bribiescas is also nice and understanding and a wonderful lecturer, but what I did not appreciate was him telling us AFTER the final exam that he planned on changing the grading structure. Throughout the course, he kept saying that there would be no curve and no change to the grading (even though people were struggling due to COVID and asking for grading changes), that 90 and above = A/A-, 80 and above = B's, but all of a sudden during finals period we got an email saying he would drop the lowest midterm score (because of COVID complications) and so everyone's grade was bumped up significantly -- but this was already PAST the Credit/D deadline. he should have informed us beforehand. the bump was definitely appreciated by people who didn't Credit/D though.
Weaknesses: there should have been more focus on how eugenics has impacted science. there was very little discussion about this even though it is pretty important when talking about science pertaining to humans. also, tests were not a good measure of knowledge at all. they only tested memorization of the course material, no critical thinking skills whatsoever and that would be fine if the exams were fair but they weren't. the exams were hard and nitpicky. the questions were not straightforward and the answers needed to be very detailed in order to get full points. it was tedious and not at all a productive academic measurement. it would make more sense for us to submit short research papers/short presentations in lieu of the exams where we dove more deeply into course content and actually showed our learning by incorporating course content rather than just regurgitating details. plus, the exams weren't cumulative so we'd end up forgetting information anyway. but in general, it's really not helpful to just have courses where we can't fully exercise critical thinking skills or meaningful exploration of the material because all we're doing is memorizing what the instructor says and trying to remember as much as possible so we can just repeat it on an exam.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure! It's a pretty good science credit if you're looking for one. Professor Bribiescas is an engaging lecturer, and he's very concerned with a non-Western analysis of evolutionary biology.
Yes, only if you're truly interested in the topic.

I would recommend this class to someone interested in the topic or someone just looking for an interesting science credit, because the material is useful for understanding our own bodies and for understanding modern medicine.
Yes. This course is very interesting and helps you understand humanity better. I think it is taught in a way that is both manageable and interesting to people of all science backgrounds.

Yeah, it is a good science credit. You will learn a good amount and it isn't technical science, just main ideas. The Professor is super passionate about the subject which makes it fun. It isn'y taught in the most engaging way, however. Just literally taking notes for an hour and fifteen minutes while he lectures.

Definitely!  This course is great for humanities and STEM majors alike.  It is very interesting and easy to understand, even for students not from a STEM background.  The course is very well organized and Professor Bribiescas is such an engaging instructor.
I would recommend as a credit D. Im not dumb but my grades in this class (with legitimate effort) just did not improve
I would not recommend this course if the student is taking it for a grade! I would only recommend to students who already familiar with the discipline or who are taking the class "credit/d"

Yes  if you need an easy science credit. No if you actually want to get something out of the class. Felt very repetitive even for someone with no background in the subject. But also I learned some interesting things
Yes!!! Super interesting with amazing instructors and TFs.
I would recommend it to someone who is interested in anthropology or who seeks to fulfill a science distributional requirement.

I think this is a good class if you want to learn interesting things about biology and anthropologythe material was fairly engaging, and the insights felt relevant. It's not too much of a time commitment, either: as long as you keep up with the lectures and attend sections, studying for midterms and doing the psets felt very manageable.
No.
Yes, if you need an interesting science credit that isn't necessarily a gut.  I wouldn't say it's hard or easy but I did ended up enjoying this class, and I've dropped two science credits before.

Yes, it is not a gut however (unless you're really into the material): like many other "not-guts," the content is straightforward but there is a lot of material to memorize. The worst is that there is no practice material so it's hard practicing material going into it.

Yes! As I said above, this class is fantastic. It gives you a broad insight into the field of anthropology that is useful for science and non-science majors alike. Professor Bribiescas is engaging and highly knowledgeable about the subject material and much of our readings feature his research.
It is not a gut science credit at all, but if you learn the material it is actually very interesting.

I would recommend the course, but they should know its not a gut. They should enter with the hope of learning something about human evolution and life history. If they pay attention and give it some effort, they will. Youll definitely learn more than in a course like Intro Biological Anthro.
Yes if they are interested in the variation in different health factors across human populations and/or evolutionary theory.
Yes I would because even for non-STEM students the course material is decipherable and relevant to other aspects of life.
Yes i would but be ready to work
Only if they can Cr/D it or are really great at memorization.
Yes, I think it's a really great intro to biological anthropology course for those interested in the field, and a casual but not gutty science credit for non-majors.
Yes!! Strongly recommend because it is a fair science credit and prof B is an amazing lecturer! It was so interesting to also read many of his papers and listen to him speak about his research.
Yes! Took this for a science credit and really loved it. Would take it again even without needing a science credit
Yes absolutely! Great if youve always wanted an explanation for evolutionary things in day to day life

Yeah, I guess so. I came in needing another science credit, and this was more work than I was expecting (sometimes weekly readings were quite long and studying for midterms took a while), but also I clearly got quite a bit out of it. I think about humans slightly differently than before, and the idea of evolutionary trade-offs is ever-present in my mind now. Also, learned some cool trivia/themes regarding how humans respond to e.g. environmental factors, so overall a successful course.
I would only recommend it to another student if they were a STEM major, or willing and able to put a lot of independent time and effort into the calss.
Yes. Professor Bribiescas was great and his own studies and experiences in different countries really added to the lecturees.
No, only if it was a major requirement. This class is not worth the stress and difficulty for a science credit

i wouldn't recommend this course without having a great interest in the subject and prerequisite knowledge of biological anthropology. the things studied are interesting and relevant, but can be hard to grasp in exam settings, whereas problem sets are much more digestible.
Yes, I loved this class, Prof. Bribiescas is very kind and funny and I looked forward to the readings each week

I would because at the end of the day I thought the concepts were very interesting. Life history trade-offs provided a unique lens through which to understand evolution and stages in our lives as humans.

Yes, if this sort of thing interests you like it did for me! I wanted to get a science credit and was also interested in picking up some cursory knowledge of evolutionary biology and that is what I got. Well taught, good standard college course honestly. Not much to complain about. We did the readings, attended lectures, and took tests, and it was all fine!
No there are better guts. Do not take as gut
Yes. For anyone looking for a not too hardcore science course or interested in ecology and evolutionary biology, this is a great introductory class.

I would definitely recommend this course. I thought the course material was engaging and Professor Bribiescas was a great lecturer. As someone not from a science background, I found the course captivating while still accessible; if you are looking for an interesting science credit, I think this is a great choice!

i would recommend it ONLY if they change the course structure. 75% of your grade was based on exams that solely test memorization which was not at all a good measure of knowledge and was not engaging. plus, the exams asked very specific questions and if you didn't remember the details, you were docked points. he should have a mixture of exams and short research papers where we meaningfully engage with course content instead of just regurgitate information. the course content was pretty interesting though and relevant to our every day lives. but what was also lacking was discussion about eugenics. there should have been more focus on how eugenics has impacted science, as it is pretty important when talking about science pertaining to humans
